head.title: Dip Into a Book, Physically and Virtually

hedline.hl1: Dip Into a Book, Physically and Virtually

abstract.p: Richard Bruce letter on Internet distribution of Stephen King's new novel suggests that Amazon.com and other Web bookstores publish first several pages of all books for readers to browse online (July 25 article)

block.p: Stephen King's new book, distributed through his Web site and Amazon.com (Business Day, July 25), leads me to wonder why it is that Amazon.com and other Web bookstores do not normally give us the first 5 or 10 pages of their novels. And why don't they give us the first few pages of nonfiction works along with the table of contents and the index?
Surely this would make the Web bookstores much more competitive with local bookstores that allow you to read as much of the book as you want.

And it seems likely that the change would help publishers. Their books receive wear and tear through test reading at traditional bookstores. On the Web there is no wear and tear, and they could give us just enough content to make a fair evaluation of the book without giving away the whole thing.
Perhaps even the local bookstores could gain a little if people did their test reading at Web stores and bought locally.
